citation.article-title: Desulfuromonas chloroethenica sp. nov. uses tetrachloroethylene and trichloroethylene as electron acceptors.

p.s: Description of Desulfiromonas chloroethenica sp. nov.
Desulfiromonas chloroethenica (chlo.ro.e.the'ni.ca.hi. L. adj. chloroethenicus, -a, -um, pertaining to chloroethene, as the organism utilizes such compound[s] as electron acceptor[s])
Cells are rod shaped with rounded ends and occur singly, 0.6 μm wide by 1.0 to 1.7 μm long.
Strictly anaerobic chemoorganotrophs which grow in a freshwater mineral medium.
Acetate or pyruvate can be used as electron donor.
Fumarate, polysulfide, Fe(III) NTA, PCE, and trichloroethylene used as electron acceptors for growth.
PCE and trichloroethylene are dechlorinated to cis-dichloroethylene and chloride.
A drop in the pH of the medium is observed if adequate bicarbonate is not included (0.35 to 0.7%).
pH optimum near 7.4 with growth occurring between 6.5 and 7.4.
The temperature range of growth on PCE is 21 to 31°C.
Habitat is freshwater sediments contaminated with chlorinated ethylenes.
Type strain has been deposited in the American Type Culture Collection (accession no. ATCC 700295).
